chunks.en: As frustrated as Ke Jie being defeated by AlphaGo

An experienced programmer who codes like a god can quickly implement requirements and locate and solve problems, relying on a wealth of knowledge, active programming thinking, and ready problem retrieval capabilities.
But these abilities accumulated through time and experience seem insignificant in the face of AI.

It seems that an ordinary programmer can also directly implement complex requirements through AI.
How much competitiveness does such an experienced programmer have? It's like Ke Jie facing AlphaGo, too frustrating.

But Go is not just a project that focuses on the results of the competition. More attention is paid to the process of human competition. But when coding in a company, the boss only cares about the results.
How long can this last? So frustrating
In fact, what frustrated Ke Jie was not losing. It is that self-supervised reinforcement learning AI will subvert existing technical paths.

chunks.en: The good moves they thought were good are like garbage in the eyes of AI. They simply cannot understand the good moves in the eyes of AI.
In a very short period of time, AI easily obtained a better solution that humans have not been able to explore for thousands of years (whether it is the best remains to be considered).
AI has destroyed Ke Jie's knowledge system of more than ten or twenty years.
This has not yet happened in the field of programming, but that day will come.
For example, the various frameworks, development processes, and rules designed for software engineering and team collaboration are actually a constraint on software development efficiency.
When AI can directly output binary executable files, it will be the AlphaZero moment in the programming field.

chunks.zh: çŸ¥è¯†åˆ†ä¸ºä¸‰ç§ï¼š ä½ çŸ¥é“ä½ çŸ¥é“çš„ï¼Œ ä½ çŸ¥é“ä½ ä¸çŸ¥é“çš„ï¼Œå’Œä½ ä¸çŸ¥é“ä½ ä¸çŸ¥é“çš„ã€‚
chunks.en: There are three types of knowledge: what you know you know, what you know you don't know, and what you don't know you don't know.
If it is the third type, even if the one who answers you is an omniscient and omnipotent god, you don't even know how to ask.

Therefore, in today's AI era, we should try to expand our knowledge as much as possible. We may not understand it, but we must know that there is such a thing, at least know what to ask, instead of fighting AI to the death on certain depths.
Then become an ordinary programmer and use AI to implement complex requirements. Wouldn't that give you a sense of accomplishment?
Correct a small mistake: Add 'äº' after 'å¤§è´¥' in the title. Ke Jie has never defeated AlphaGoğŸ˜œ

@sentinelK It feels like it is developing exponentially. When GPT first became popular two or three years ago, I firmly believed that the current question-and-answer format was far from replacing programmers, but now it has developed to the point where it can directly create executable projects. Too scary.

@zhangH258 I was originally complacent about solving problems with my own knowledge and experience, but then I let AI analyze my code, and it seemed to be full of loopholes and vulnerable. I was deeply shocked.

chunks.en: Human legs cannot run faster than cars, but they can become car drivers. It is only a matter of time before humans are surpassed by AI. Be a driver in the AI â€‹â€‹era.
Ke Jie was highly arrogant and even criticized Lee Sedol. Are you also highly arrogant towards AI?

@GeorgeWai "Winning at chess is because you can calculate the optimal path through permutations and combinations." But the current large language models and programming models are repeatedly proving that human programming, writing, and even language have statistical patterns.
You think you are creating, compiling, and expressing. But in reality, it is just divergence and randomness under a certain statistical pattern.
The reason why humans have not discovered it is because the power of the human brain is too low, and it is not good at discovering statistical connections under big data.
What's more, most production activities follow established methodologies, that is, existing optimal routes and experiences. It just depends on whether you can admit and accept it.

chunks.en: DeepMind's AlphaGo documentary from a few years ago recorded the enormous psychological shift humans experience when facing AI. This shift is not only in the Go world, but will inevitably play out in all walks of life in the future.

Not really. In the audio and video aspects that I am familiar with, many of the codes given by AI are hallucinations. Or the requirements cannot be met, and there are also errors in optimizing performance.
Then become an AI trainer and spur it on.
If Ordinary Programmer + AI = Experienced Programmer, Coding God Programmer, and AI doesn't need a salary, then why are ordinary programmers frustrated?

chunks.en: No matter how hard you try to build up your knowledge, you can't compete with AI, but AI may not be able to think of the ideas that pop up in your head occasionally.

Feeling plus one, I have been using GPT for a long time. Recently, I wanted to combine it with a project and conduct in-depth research and understanding. As a result, I deeply felt that the speed at which I read this knowledge could not keep up with the speed of external updates.
@Pursue9 Then the boss will give you the salary of an ordinary programmer.
@ulala ğŸ˜Ÿ Yes, defeated by
@Cooky Yes, so far AI has not completely replaced it. But the speed of AI development is too rapid.
Think in reverse, become the boss.
The ability to solve problems is constantly accumulated. Although the solutions given by AI seem correct, there are many special circumstances in reality.
